Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Density-enhanced data assimilation for hyperbolic balance laws
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research addresses the urgent need to develop efficient computational tools to process the dramatically increasing amounts of observational data. Management of many complex systems (e.g., traffic) has to confront the uncertainty in both their current and future state. This uncertainty typically increases with time, leading to less accurate and useful predictions. Thus, it is important to develop practical methods for ?adjusting? the probabilistic state of the system and reducing uncertainty using observational data. This approach is broadly referred to as data assimilation. We will develop novel techniques for incorporating observational data to reduce uncertainty in predictions in two particular areas of national interest: fluid dynamics (e.g., flood forecasting) and traffic management. Both are of vital importance to sustainable development of our society.

We propose to develop a novel data assimilation framework for physical processes whose time-dynamics is described by hyperbolic conservation laws. This framework takes advantage of a kinetic representation of hyperbolic systems and, thus, availability of explicit deterministic equations for the time evolution of probability density function for dependent variables. These equations can often be derived and solved exactly, yielding explicit analytical solutions for the marginal and joint probability density functions. For systems of hyperbolic conservation laws an appropriate closure assumption is needed. Thus, the proposed framework relies on the kinetic representation, which takes the form of linear equations for joint probability density functions. Bayesian updating is utilized to incorporate observations into the prediction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project yielded a computationally efficient data assimilation methodology applicable to spatially extended dynamical systems whose temporal evolution is governed by (a system of) hyperbolic conservation laws. Examples of such problems, studied in this project, include vehicular traffic management and leak detection in water-distribution networks. Previously, coarse discretizations of hyperbolic conservation laws are used to construct various extensions of the Kalman filter. This imposes severe restrictions on the dimension of the discretized system and often misrepresents major features of the continuous model. The proposed research alleviated this situation by taking advantage of analytical techniques for hyperbolic conservation laws. The rigorous mathematical analysis carried out in this project lays the foundation for significant advances in data assimilation techniques for hyperbolic systems in general and for the two above-mentioned application areas in particular.

Intellectual Merit. The project led to the development of computationally efficient numerical methods for data assimilations in problems described macroscopically by hyperbolic conservation laws. We demonstrated that the density-enhanced techniques perform well in both quantification of predictive uncertainty and data assimilation. In a series of papers, we have made analytical advances to construct the update step in the data assimilation procedure and developed efficient computational techniques to handle observational data in real time. We also initiated research, and published early results, on the optimal spatial and temporal data sampling criteria.

Broader Impacts. Hyperbolic conservation laws are used to model a broad range of physical phenomena. Therefore, the project yielded the computational algorithms that are applicable to many practical problems where the prediction step is described by such models (see the two examples above, as well as forecast of flood events). Our data assimilation techniques provide an accurate and efficient framework for real-time forecasting of such systems. In addition, excessive data-acquisition can potentially overwhelm the system, and our optimal sampling criteria helps ensure sufficient accuracy under optimal spatial/temporal sampling frequency. Specific technical outcomes of this project were published in multiple articles in the leading peer-reviewed journals, and presented at many conferences on mathematical modeling, and hydrology and water resources.
